title: Mustafa Vehbi Koç
text:
Mustafa Vehbi Koç (October 29, 1960 – January 21, 2016) was a <a href="Turkish%20people">Turkish</a> businessman and a third generation member of the <a href="Ko%C3%A7%20family">Koç family</a>. He is best known as the <a href="chairman">chairman</a> of <a href="Ko%C3%A7%20Holding">Koç Holding</a>, a position he held from 2003 until his death in 2016.
Private life.
Mustafa Koç was born to <a href="Rahmi%20Ko%C3%A7">Rahmi Koç</a>, the second-generation member of <a href="Ko%C3%A7%20family">Koç family</a> on October 29, 1960. He had two younger brothers <a href="Mehmet%20%C3%96mer%20Ko%C3%A7">Mehmet Ömer Koç</a> (born 1962) and <a href="Ali%20Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m%20Ko%C3%A7">Ali Yıldırım Koç</a> (born 1967). Graduating from <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>’s international boarding high school <a href="Lyceum%20Alpinum%20Zuoz">Lyceum Alpinum Zuoz</a> in 1980, Mustafa Koç received his <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a> in <a href="business%20administration">business administration</a> from <a href="George%20Washington%20University">George Washington University</a> in 1984.
Koç was married to Caroline Giraud and was father of two daughters Esra Marianne Çiğdem Koç and Aylin Elif Koç.
Professional career.
After graduation, Koç started working as a Consultant at <a href="Tofa%C5%9F">Tofaş</a>. Continuing his career as sales manager and later as assistant general manager for Sales at Ram Dış Ticaret, in 1992, he joined <a href="Ko%C3%A7%20Holding">Koç Holding</a> to serve as vice president.
Working at Koç Holding, Turkey's largest industrial conglomerate and the only Turkish company listed in <a href="Fortune%20500">Fortune 500</a>, for all of his career, Koç became a board member in 2001. Assuming the responsibility as vice chairman the following year, he took over the position of chairman from <a href="Rahmi%20Ko%C3%A7">Rahmi Koç</a>, his retired father, in 2003. Mustafa Koç was also the chairman for the High Advisory Council to <a href="T%C3%9CS%C4%B0AD">TÜSİAD</a>, the Turkish Industry and Business Association, between 2003 until 2015. Between 2006 and 2013, he held office as Honorary Consul for <a href="Finland">Finland</a>, as well as being a member of Council for Foreign Economic Affairs for the Istanbul Chamber of Industry. Koç also held various international positions during his career, including positions in <a href="JP%20Morgan">JP Morgan</a>’s International Council, <a href="Rolls-Royce">Rolls-Royce</a> International’s Advisory Board, and <a href="Bilderberg%20Meetings">Bilderberg Meetings</a>’ Executive Board. He was awarded the Cavaliere D’Industria medal by the <a href="Italy">Italian</a> government in 2005.
Death and legacy.
Mustafa Koç suffered a <a href="heart%20attack">heart attack</a> during a fitness exercise at his home and died on January 21, 2016. He was buried at <a href="Zincirlikuyu%20Cemetery">Zincirlikuyu Cemetery</a> next to his grandfather's grave. A documentary film titled "Dreams and Memories" about the legacy of Mustafa Koç was produced in 2017.
He had been a lifelong <a href="sports">sports</a> enthusiast, with his hobbies ranging from <a href="sailing">sailing</a>, <a href="Aeromodelling">Aeromodelling</a> and <a href="golf">golf</a>, to <a href="scuba%20diving">scuba diving</a> and <a href="equestrianism">horseback riding</a>. A sports award named after Mustafa Koç was established in 2017 to honor his memory. Celebrating the ideals and merits of sportsmanship, the "Mustafa V. Koç Sports Award" is judged by the <a href="Turkish%20Olympic%20Committee">Turkish Olympic Committee</a>.
